title: Gladys Mills Phipps
text:
Gladys Mills Phipps (June 19, 1883 - October 19, 1970) was a <a href="United%20States">United States</a> <a href="socialite">socialite</a>, sportsperson, and a <a href="thoroughbred">thoroughbred</a> <a href="horse%20racing">racehorse</a> owner and <a href="horse%20breeding">breeder</a> who began the <a href="Phipps%20family">Phipps family</a> dynasty in American horse racing. She was known as the "first lady of the turf".
Early life.
She was born in <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a> on June 19, 1883 to Ruth Livingston (1855–1920) and <a href="Ogden%20Mills%20%28financier%29">Ogden Mills</a> (1856–1929). She had a twin sister, <a href="Beatrice%20Mills%20Forbes%2C%208th%20Countess%20of%20Granard">Beatrice, Countess Granard</a> (1883–1972), and a brother, <a href="Ogden%20L.%20Mills">Ogden Livingston Mills</a> (1884–1937) who served as the <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20the%20Treasury">United States Secretary of the Treasury</a>.
Career.
This sportswoman was an avid <a href="ice%20skating">ice skater</a> and an excellent <a href="golf">golf</a>er; she won a number of tournaments, including a <a href="match%20play">match play</a> championship at the <a href="Newport%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Newport, Rhode Island</a> golf course in which she beat her male counterparts. She was, however, first and foremost a lover of horses. Her father had owned racing stables in the United States and in <a href="France">France</a>. Her twin, Beatrice, would inherit the French stable and become a leading owner in that country. Gladys Phipps became involved in the sport of Thoroughbred racing in 1926, when she and her brother <a href="Ogden%20L.%20Mills">Ogden L. Mills</a> established the highly successful <a href="Wheatley%20Stable">Wheatley Stable</a>. Both of her children became involved in <a href="Thoroughbred%20horse%20racing">Thoroughbred horse racing</a>.
Personal life.
In 1907, Gladys Mills married <a href="Henry%20Carnegie%20Phipps">Henry Carnegie Phipps</a> (1879–1953), son of the wealthy <a href="Pittsburgh%2C%20Pennsylvania">Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania</a> businessman, <a href="Henry%20Phipps%2C%20Jr.">Henry Phipps</a>. Together they had:
Gladys Mills Phipps died on October 19, 1970 in <a href="Roslyn%2C%20New%20York">Roslyn, New York</a>.
Philanthropy.
Following her brother's death in 1937, Gladys Mills Phipps inherited their parents' mansion at <a href="Staatsburg%2C%20New%20York">Staatsburg, New York</a>. In 1938, she gave the house and to the State of New York.
